r

knight
Lord Governo
r

page.lettertext:
fol.162r
S
r
Tho. Bodley to S
r
Robert Sydney
The more that I have to impart to yo
r
L
ordship
the lesse is my leasure to impart it as I would
For my often meeting w
t
e
states
and
Councel
and my necessarie dispatches into
England,
doe so occupie all my time, as I am forced to
be short or silent w
t
my frindes.
S
r
John Norreis
hath sent his letters and messengers to cause
e
companies to marche: and in case they cannot
for
e contrey, that then every Captain shall
casse his owne company. The states to with-
tand his proceeding, have sent their letters of
charge, to all their townes and officers, where
the Englishe are in Garrison, not to minister
any meanes whereby they may passe. They
have also framed a forme of Protest, whiche
they have sent to S
r
John Norreis, w
th
an authentical
Insinuation of
e same to
S
r
Francis Vere
,
S
r
Thomas Morgan
,
S
r
Edward Norreis
, and my
self. And to tell yow very truly, I never
see them in any thing so perplexed as in this;
whereof I knowe not w
at
successe S
r
John Norreis
doth ex pect. But for myself I am against
his cassing of companies, it tending to no
other but to
e ruine of
e companies, to
e losse
of those townes, where
e Englishe only are in
Garrison, and to
e general detriment of
e
state of these Provinces. Because in this mater
I am put in some trust, and must answear
for my trust, if I doe not consaile for
e best,
I am fully resolved, w
at
soever other course
shall be taken by others, to direct mine owne
actions to
e indemnitie of
e contrey. I am
not unmindful of yo
r
L. request, about yo
r
cornet
of
horse, but I take it to be
a
fitter opportunitie to move it when this mater of S
r
John Norreis is somwhat more overblowen.
And so for this p
nt
present
I bidde yo
r
L
ordship
most hartely farewell.
From
e Hage Fe
b
9 A
o
1590.
Yo
r
L. at commandement Tho. Bodley
